articles.headline: A Split-Up of Insurers of Bonds Is Considered
articles.snippet: Proponents of the idea say such a step could restore confidence in the financial markets broadly, and specifically in the $2.6 trillion municipal bond market.
articles.abstract: Proponents of the idea say such a step could restore confidence in the financial markets broadly, and specifically in the $2.6 trillion municipal bond market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Regulators and bankers racing to bolster troubled bond insurance companies are considering splitting the firms into two parts: one for safe municipal debt and the other for riskier mortgage-related securities.

articles.headline: By Making Holocaust Personal to Pupils, Sarkozy Stirs Anger
articles.snippet: France’s president has touched off protests with a plan to have students learn the life stories of children killed by the Nazis.
articles.abstract: France’s president has touched off protests with a plan to have students learn the life stories of children killed by the Nazis.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy dropped an intellectual bombshell this week, surprising the nation and touching off waves of protest with his revision of the school curriculum: beginning next fall, he said, every fifth grader will have to learn the life story of one of the 11,000 French children killed by the Nazis in the Holocaust.

articles.headline: All-in-One Telecom Packages: The Savings Don’t Come Simple
articles.snippet: “Bundling” sounds sweet, doesn’t it? Like swaddling a baby. But don’t let it fool you — the communications version of it is not such a simple pleasure.
articles.abstract: “Bundling” sounds sweet, doesn’t it? Like swaddling a baby. But don’t let it fool you — the communications version of it is not such a simple pleasure.
articles.lead_paragraph: This month, my husband and I decided to make a major move in our lives.

articles.headline: China Didn’t Check Drug Supplier, Files Show
articles.snippet: An ingredient in a blood thinner linked to four deaths was made at an uncertified plant in China that was not inspected.
articles.abstract: An ingredient in a blood thinner linked to four deaths was made at an uncertified plant in China that was not inspected.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Chinese factory that supplies much of the active ingredient for a brand of a blood thinner that has been linked to four deaths in the United States is not certified by China’s drug regulators to make pharmaceutical products, according to records and interviews.
articles.byline: By Walt Bogdanich and Jake Hooker

articles.headline: For ‘EcoMoms,’ Saving Earth Begins at Home
articles.snippet: Move over, Tupperware. A new wave of parties is about waste-free lunches and energy-efficient laundry.
articles.abstract: Move over, Tupperware. A new wave of parties is about waste-free lunches and energy-efficient laundry.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN RAFAEL, Calif.  The women gathered in the airy living room, wine poured and pleasantries exchanged. In no time, the conversation turned lively  not about the literary merits of Geraldine Brooks or Cormac McCarthy but the pitfalls of antibacterial hand sanitizers and how to retool the laundry using only cold water and biodegradable detergent during non-prime-time energy hours (after 7 p.m.).

articles.headline: F.D.A. Seeks to Broaden Range of Use for Drugs
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration’s proposed rules would allow drug and device makers to provide doctors with medical journal articles about product uses that have not been approved by the F.D.A.
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration’s proposed rules would allow drug and device makers to provide doctors with medical journal articles about product uses that have not been approved by the F.D.A.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When federal drug regulators approve a medicine for sale, they limit how drug makers sell it. A drug approved to treat only breast cancer cannot be marketed for lung cancer even if some studies suggest that the medicine may save lung patients.

articles.headline: Taps for HD DVD as Wal-Mart Backs Blu-ray
articles.snippet: High-definition DVD died Friday after a brief illness. The cause of death was the decision by Wal-Mart to stock only HD DVDs and players using the Blu-ray format.
articles.abstract: High-definition DVD died Friday after a brief illness. The cause of death was the decision by Wal-Mart to stock only HD DVDs and players using the Blu-ray format.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  HD DVD, the beloved format of Toshiba and three Hollywood studios, died Friday after a brief illness. The cause of death was determined to be the decision by Wal-Mart to stock only high-definition DVDs and players using the Blu-ray format.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Eric A. Taub

articles.headline: Gunman Showed Few Hints of Trouble
articles.snippet: Steve Kazmierczak was seen as personable and an excellent student, not a brooding outcast.
articles.abstract: Steve Kazmierczak was seen as personable and an excellent student, not a brooding outcast.
articles.lead_paragraph: DeKALB, Ill.  Steve Kazmierczak, the man who walked silently into a classroom here on Thursday and opened fire, was not seen as struggling in college. He was not an outcast. And until recently, at least, he was not brooding.

articles.headline: Democrats Look for Way to Avoid Convention Rift
articles.snippet: Some senior Democrats plan to remain neutral for now in the presidential race in part to keep open the option to broker a peaceful resolution to a tight contest.
articles.abstract: Some senior Democrats plan to remain neutral for now in the presidential race in part to keep open the option to broker a peaceful resolution to a tight contest.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Al Gore and a number of other senior Democrats plan to remain neutral for now in the presidential race in part to keep open the option to broker a peaceful resolution to what they fear could be a bitterly divided convention, party officials and aides said Friday.
articles.byline: By Don Van Natta Jr. and Jo Becker

articles.headline: Conflict on the Menu
articles.snippet: New York City’s new rules for menu labels at chain restaurants have set off a food fight among the nation’s obesity experts.
articles.abstract: New York City’s new rules for menu labels at chain restaurants have set off a food fight among the nation’s obesity experts.
articles.lead_paragraph: New York City’s new rules for menu labels at chain restaurants have set off a food fight among the nation’s obesity experts.

articles.headline: In France, the Heads No Longer Roll
articles.snippet: In the wake of the Société Générale scandal, France’s business aristocracy finds itself in a place it never wants to be: the spotlight.
articles.abstract: In the wake of the Société Générale scandal, France’s business aristocracy finds itself in a place it never wants to be: the spotlight.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  OF all the clubs in the world, the Club of 100 in France may be the most exclusive. Its ranks include leaders in business, politics and law, but it’s the admission policy that really makes the Club des Cent, as it is known here, truly remarkable: only when an existing member dies is space made for a new one.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: Old Clinton Ties and Voters’ Sway Tug at Delegates
articles.snippet: The dwindling group of undecided Democratic superdelegates is being caught in strong political crosscurrents.
articles.abstract: The dwindling group of undecided Democratic superdelegates is being caught in strong political crosscurrents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The dwindling group of elected officials and party leaders publicly undecided in the Democratic presidential contest  about 300 out of the 795 so-called superdelegates who may determine the party’s nominee  includes at least 30 who have a long and often personal history with the Clinton family.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Farhana Hossain

articles.headline: Arcane Market Is Next to Face Big Credit Test
articles.snippet: The market for credit insurance will be put to the test as a looming economic downturn strains companies’ finances.
articles.abstract: The market for credit insurance will be put to the test as a looming economic downturn strains companies’ finances.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few Americans have heard of credit default swaps, arcane financial instruments invented by Wall Street about a decade ago. But if the economy keeps slowing, credit default swaps, like subprime mortgages, may become a household term.

articles.headline: The Power of Whimsy
articles.snippet: By one rough estimate, Sandra Boynton has sold around a half-billion cards, which may make her one of the best-selling card creators of all time.
articles.abstract: By one rough estimate, Sandra Boynton has sold around a half-billion cards, which may make her one of the best-selling card creators of all time.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANDRA BOYNTON’S studio, in a converted barn next to her Connecticut home, bears the milestones of her singular career: a long rack of greeting cards featuring quirkily drawn animals; a room full of small, sturdy children’s books, with names like “Snuggle Puppy!” and “Barnyard Dance!”; and, upstairs, where she does much of her work, old-time radios and jukeboxes representing her more recent foray into music CDs for children.

articles.headline: The Insiders Are Selling, but Why?
articles.snippet: The credit crisis appears to be knocking on the doors of commercial educators.
articles.abstract: The credit crisis appears to be knocking on the doors of commercial educators.
articles.lead_paragraph: TROUBLES in the subprime mortgage arena are seeping into other markets, like credit cards, auto loans and college debt issued to people with risky profiles. So it isn’t surprising that stocks of for-profit education companies  which are heavily reliant on students’ access to easy money  have fallen in recent months.

articles.headline: Stifled, Egypt’s Young Turn to Islamic Fervor
articles.snippet: Forced to put off marriage and thwarted by a lackluster economy, many young people turn to religion for solace.
articles.abstract: Forced to put off marriage and thwarted by a lackluster economy, many young people turn to religion for solace.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The concrete steps leading from Ahmed Muhammad Sayyid’s first-floor apartment sag in the middle, worn down over time, like Mr. Sayyid himself. Once, Mr. Sayyid had a decent job and a chance to marry. But his fiancée’s family canceled the engagement because after two years, he could not raise enough money to buy an apartment and furniture.

articles.headline: Tax Scandal in Germany Fans Complaints of Inequity
articles.snippet: Hundreds of people, including several who are household names, are under investigation on suspicion that they evaded taxes by steering money to Liechtenstein.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of people, including several who are household names, are under investigation on suspicion that they evaded taxes by steering money to Liechtenstein.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  For wealthy Germans, many of whom have long hidden their money outside the country to avoid its high taxes, this has been a weekend of high anxiety. For their fellow citizens, it has been a riveting spectacle, dominating the public discussion for days.
articles.byline: By Carter Dougherty and Mark Landler

articles.headline: No Lull in Mortgage Pitches
articles.snippet: The mortgage market may be in a historic upheaval, but mortgage companies continue to pump out upbeat advertisements.
articles.abstract: The mortgage market may be in a historic upheaval, but mortgage companies continue to pump out upbeat advertisements.
articles.lead_paragraph: The mortgage market may be in a historic upheaval, but mortgage companies continue to pump out upbeat advertisements.

articles.headline: Kosovo Declares Its Independence From Serbia
articles.snippet: Greeted with euphoria by ethnic Albanians, the move brings to a climax a showdown with Serbia and Russia.
articles.abstract: Greeted with euphoria by ethnic Albanians, the move brings to a climax a showdown with Serbia and Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRISTINA, Kosovo  The province of Kosovo declared independence from Serbia on Sunday, sending tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians streaming through the streets to celebrate what they hoped was the end of a long and bloody struggle for national self-determination.

articles.headline: After China Ships Out iPhones, Smugglers Make It a Return Trip
articles.snippet: The popularity of the iPhone is defying Apple’s attempt to slowly introduce it in new markets.
articles.abstract: The popularity of the iPhone is defying Apple’s attempt to slowly introduce it in new markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  Factories here churn out iPhones that are exported to the United States and Europe. Then thousands of them are smuggled right back into China.

articles.headline: Government to Control Struggling British Bank
articles.snippet: The nationalization of Northern Rock, the ailing mortgage lender, was the first such action in more than a decade and a huge blow for Prime Minister Gordon Brown.
articles.abstract: The nationalization of Northern Rock, the ailing mortgage lender, was the first such action in more than a decade and a huge blow for Prime Minister Gordon Brown.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  The British government announced on Sunday that it would bring Northern Rock, the struggling mortgage lender, under its control. It was the first nationalization of a bank in more than a decade and a huge blow for the administration of Prime Minister Gordon Brown.

articles.headline: Guantánamo, Evil and Zany in Pop Culture
articles.snippet: In popular culture, Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, has become shorthand for hopeless imprisonment and isolation.
articles.abstract: In popular culture, Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, has become shorthand for hopeless imprisonment and isolation.
articles.lead_paragraph: This spring, the stoner screwball movie of 2004, “Harold and Kumar Go to White Castle,” will get a sequel. This time, because of some unfortunate confusion on an airplane between a “bong” and a “bomb,” our slacker antiheroes are shipped off to the moviemakers’ idea of the worst prison imaginable.

articles.headline: McCain Facing Delicate Choice: A Role for Bush
articles.snippet: John McCain must decide how best to use President Bush to win over conservatives without driving away independents and moderate Democrats.
articles.abstract: John McCain must decide how best to use President Bush to win over conservatives without driving away independents and moderate Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain’s campaign advisers will ask the White House to deploy President Bush for major Republican fund-raising, but they do not want the president to appear too often at his side, top aides to Mr. McCain said Sunday.

articles.headline: Of All the Hurdles to a Merger, View on Technology Is the Highest
articles.snippet: A smooth integration between Microsoft and Yahoo will not be a matter of simply swapping one set of software or hardware for another. It may hinge on changing deep-seated mind-sets.
articles.abstract: A smooth integration between Microsoft and Yahoo will not be a matter of simply swapping one set of software or hardware for another. It may hinge on changing deep-seated mind-sets.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  If Microsoft succeeds in its conquest of Yahoo, what then?
articles.byline: By John Markoff and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: News Isn’t Wasted on the Young
articles.snippet: Can newscasts retain the college crowd beyond the elections?
articles.abstract: Can newscasts retain the college crowd beyond the elections?
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Tuesday, Barack Obama stood in front of 15,000 shouting supporters in Madison, Wis., basking in wins in Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia. In addition to issuing a classic call to arms for the rest of the campaign, Mr. Obama took time out to welcome any Republicans to his bandwagon.
